title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: members, contributors, leaders pledge make participation community harassment-free experience everyone, regardless age, body size, visible invisible disability, ethnicity, sex characteristics, gender identity expression, level experience, education, socio-economic status, nationality, personal appearance, race, caste, color, religion, sexual identity orientation. pledge act interact ways contribute open, welcoming, diverse, inclusive, healthy community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Examples behavior contributes positive environment community include: Demonstrating empathy kindness toward people respectful differing opinions, viewpoints, experiences Giving gracefully accepting constructive feedback Accepting responsibility apologizing affected mistakes, learning experience Focusing best just us individuals, overall community Examples unacceptable behavior include: use sexualized language imagery, sexual attention advances kind Trolling, insulting derogatory comments, personal political attacks Public private harassment Publishing others’ private information, physical email address, without explicit permission conduct reasonably considered inappropriate professional setting

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders responsible clarifying enforcing standards acceptable behavior take appropriate fair corrective action response behavior deem inappropriate, threatening, offensive, harmful. Community leaders right responsibility remove, edit, reject comments, commits, code, wiki edits, issues, contributions aligned Code Conduct, communicate reasons moderation decisions appropriate.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct applies within community spaces, also applies individual officially representing community public spaces. Examples representing community include using official e-mail address, posting via official social media account, acting appointed representative online offline event.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Instances abusive, harassing, otherwise unacceptable behavior may reported community leaders responsible enforcement fascinatingfingers@icloud.com. complaints reviewed investigated promptly fairly. community leaders obligated respect privacy security reporter incident.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community leaders follow Community Impact Guidelines determining consequences action deem violation Code Conduct:

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Use inappropriate language behavior deemed unprofessional unwelcome community. Consequence: private, written warning community leaders, providing clarity around nature violation explanation behavior inappropriate. public apology may requested.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: violation single incident series actions. Consequence: warning consequences continued behavior. interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, specified period time. includes avoiding interactions community spaces well external channels like social media. Violating terms may lead temporary permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: serious violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior. Consequence: temporary ban sort interaction public communication community specified period time. public private interaction people involved, including unsolicited interaction enforcing Code Conduct, allowed period. Violating terms may lead permanent ban.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Community Impact: Demonstrating pattern violation community standards, including sustained inappropriate behavior, harassment individual, aggression toward disparagement classes individuals. Consequence: permanent ban sort public interaction within community.

title: Contributor Covenant Code of Conduct
text: Code Conduct adapted Contributor Covenant, version 2.1, available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/version/2/1/code_of_conduct.html. Community Impact Guidelines inspired [Mozilla’s code conduct enforcement ladder][https://github.com/mozilla/inclusion]. answers common questions code conduct, see FAQ https://www.contributor-covenant.org/faq. Translations available https://www.contributor-covenant.org/translations.

title: Contributing to letterblasteR
text: outlines propose change letterblasteR. project affiliated tidyverse aims adhere tidyverse standards conventions. Please see development contributing guide code review principles learn .

title: Contributing to letterblasteR
text: can fix typos, spelling mistakes, grammatical errors documentation directly using GitHub web interface, long changes made source file. generally means ’ll need edit roxygen2 comments .R, .Rd file. can find .R file generates .Rd reading comment first line.

title: Contributing to letterblasteR
text: want make bigger change, ’s good idea first file issue make sure someone team agrees ’s needed. ’ve found bug, please file issue illustrates bug minimal reprex (also help write unit test, needed). See guide create great issue advice.

title: Contributing to letterblasteR
text: Fork package clone onto computer. haven’t done , recommend using usethis::create_from_github("LetterblasterPress/letterblasteR", fork = TRUE). Install development dependencies devtools::install_dev_deps(), make sure package passes R CMD check running devtools::check(). R CMD check doesn’t pass cleanly, ’s good idea ask help continuing. Create Git branch pull request (PR). recommend using usethis::pr_init("brief-description--change"). Make changes, commit git, create PR running usethis::pr_push(), following prompts browser. title PR briefly describe change. body PR contain Fixes #issue-number. user-facing changes, add bullet top NEWS.md (.e. just first header). Follow style described https://style.tidyverse.org/news.html.

title: Contributing to letterblasteR
text: New code follow tidyverse style guide. can use styler package apply styles, please don’t restyle code nothing PR. use roxygen2, Markdown syntax, documentation. use testthat unit tests. Contributions test cases included easier accept.

title: Contributing to letterblasteR
text: Please note letterblasteR project released Contributor Code Conduct. contributing project agree abide terms.

title: Getting help with letterblasteR
text: Thanks using letterblasteR! filing issue, places explore pieces put together make process smooth possible.

title: Getting help with letterblasteR
text: Start making minimal reproducible example using reprex package. haven’t heard used reprex , ’re treat! Seriously, reprex make R-question-asking endeavors easier (pretty incredible ROI five ten minutes ’ll take learn ’s ). additional reprex pointers, check Get help! section tidyverse site.

title: Getting help with letterblasteR
text: Armed reprex, next step figure ask. ’s general question R coding, start community.rstudio.com, /StackOverflow. Direct questions Letterblaster Press letterblasteR R package discussion boards. ’s bug: ’re right place, file issue. ’re sure: let community help figure ! problem bug feature request, can easily return report . opening new issue, sure search issues pull requests make sure bug hasn’t reported /already fixed development version. default, search pre-populated :issue :open. can edit qualifiers (e.g. :pr, :closed) needed. example, ’d simply remove :open search issues repo, open closed.

title: Getting help with letterblasteR
text: Please patient project gets ground! may take time receive reply. think might able implement fix/improvement , check contributing guide submit pull request!

title: Harmonious layouts
text: Elements Typographic Style String harmonics

title: Harmonious layouts
text: Identify set generic (dimensionless) page layouts suitable codex-bound text.

title: Harmonious layouts
text: course, infinite ways rectangular textblock placed rectangular page. , restrict important page layout proportions compatible combinations harmonious ratios (see vignette("ratios")). , ’ll run grid search combination, considering range relative textblock sizes. Margins secondary page layout proportions calculated, round_ratios() used identify solutions serendipitously produce harmonious secondary proportions.

title: Harmonious layouts
text: page (square portrait) two-page spread textblock (portrait, different page proportions) bottom–top margins (bottom margin larger top margin) outer–top margins (outer margin equal larger top margin) outer–bottom margins
code: combos <- expand_grid(   page_ratio = ratios[ratios >= 1 & (2 / ratios) %in% ratios],   text_ratio = ratios[ratios > 1],   bt_ratio = ratios[ratios > 1],   ot_ratio = ratios[ratios >= 1],   ob_ratio = ratios ) |>   filter(page_ratio != text_ratio, ot_ratio == ob_ratio * bt_ratio)

title: Harmonious layouts
text: Next, ’ll consider secondary proportions include inner margin. overly restrictive (impossible) expect every proportion fall perfect harmony, want consider nearly perfect solutions. Given optical foreshortening created pages curve towards center spine, deviations produce slightly wider proportion may even work favor. Secondary inner-margin proportions: textblock, two-(spanning inner margins) outer–inner margins top–inner margins bottom–inner margins outer–inner (2⨉) margins, two-top–inner (2⨉) margins, two-bottom–inner (2⨉) margins, two-clarity ease development, ’ll wrap grid-search logic memoised function. glissando() function defined, can identify harmonious ratios primary layout combinations. layouts quite bit redundancy multiple nearly identical layouts fall within tolerances. Let’s one round, focusing solution zones, can choose single best layout motif. Clever trigonometry perhaps identify local maxima, resolution grid search already takes us well beyond resolution commercial printers. Finally, let’s eliminate redundancy favoring set dimensions result smallest total dissonance (measured area beyond confines ideally proportioned rectangle).
code: glissando <- memoise::memoise(   cache = cachem::cache_disk(fs::dir_create("memoise_cache")),   function(x, pct_height_min = 0.10, pct_height_max = 0.98, n = 1e5) {     message(sprintf(       "%s -- %s",       name_ratios(unique(x$page_ratio)),       name_ratios(unique(x$text_ratio))     ))      x |>       # expand dataset to include a range of textblock heights       mutate(         across(everything(), as.numeric), ## reduce object size by removing names         page_height = page_ratio,         page_width = 1,         join = 1L       ) |>       left_join(by = "join", relationship = "many-to-many", tibble(         join = 1L,         text_height = seq(           pct_height_min * unique(x$page_ratio),           pct_height_max * unique(x$page_ratio),           length.out = n         )       )) |>       select(-join) |>       # calculate margins for each layout       mutate(         text_width = text_height / text_ratio,         b_mar = (bt_ratio * (page_height - text_height)) / (bt_ratio + 1),         t_mar = (page_height - text_height) / (bt_ratio + 1),         o_mar = t_mar * ot_ratio,         i_mar = page_width - o_mar - text_width,         oi_ratio = round_ratios(o_mar, i_mar, "wider")       ) |>       filter(i_mar > 0, !is.na(oi_ratio)) |>       # calculate secondary ratios and tidy tibble       transmute(         page_ratio, # exact         page_2up_ratio = page_height / (2 * page_width), # exact         text_ratio, # exact         text_2up_ratio = round_ratios(text_height, 2 * (text_width + i_mar), "wider"),         bt_ratio, # exact         oi_ratio, # rounded          ot_ratio, # exact         ob_ratio, # exact         ti_ratio = round_ratios(t_mar, i_mar, "wider"),         bi_ratio = round_ratios(b_mar, i_mar, "wider"),         oii_ratio = round_ratios(o_mar, 2 * i_mar, "wider"),         tii_ratio = round_ratios(t_mar, 2 * i_mar, "wider"),         bii_ratio = round_ratios(b_mar, 2 * i_mar, "wider"),         text_pct = (text_height * text_width) / (page_height * page_width),         page_height, page_width,         text_height, text_width,         b_mar, t_mar, o_mar, i_mar       ) |>       drop_na() |>       mutate(across(         matches("^(page|page_2up|text|bt|ot|ob)_ratio"),         ~ ratios[name_ratios(.)]       ))   } ) layouts <- combos |>   split(with(combos, list(names(page_ratio), names(text_ratio))), drop = TRUE) |>   map_dfr(glissando) layouts <- layouts |>   bind_rows(     layouts |>       group_by(across(ends_with("ratio"))) |>       summarise(         pct_height_min = 0.9999 * min(text_height / page_height),         pct_height_max = 1.0001 * max(text_height / page_height),         .groups = "drop"       ) |>       nest(x = names(combos)) |>       transmute(x, pct_height_min, pct_height_max) |>       pmap_dfr(glissando)   ) |>   distinct() layouts <- layouts |>   mutate(     text_2up_err = (text_height * 2 * (text_width + i_mar)) -       (text_height^2 / text_2up_ratio),     oi_err = text_height * (i_mar - o_mar / oi_ratio),     ti_err = (t_mar * i_mar) - (t_mar^2 / ti_ratio),     bi_err = (b_mar * i_mar) - (b_mar^2 / bi_ratio),     oii_err = text_height * (2 * i_mar - o_mar / oii_ratio),     tii_err = (t_mar * 2 * i_mar) - (t_mar^2 / tii_ratio),     bii_err = (b_mar * 2 * i_mar) - (b_mar^2 / bii_ratio),     error = as.numeric(       abs(text_2up_err) +         2 * oi_err + 2 * ti_err + 2 * bi_err +         oii_err + tii_err + bii_err     )   )  # stopifnot(all(layouts$text_2up_err >= 0)) stopifnot(all(layouts$oi_err >= 0)) stopifnot(all(layouts$ti_err >= 0)) stopifnot(all(layouts$bi_err >= 0)) stopifnot(all(layouts$oii_err >= 0)) stopifnot(all(layouts$tii_err >= 0)) stopifnot(all(layouts$bii_err >= 0))  layouts |>   group_by(across(ends_with("ratio"))) |>   summarise(range = diff(range(text_height)), .groups = "drop") |>   with(range < 0.001) |>   all() |>   stopifnot()  layouts <- layouts |>   slice_min(error, by = ends_with("ratio")) |>   select(-ends_with("_err")) |>   mutate(across(     ends_with("ratio"),     ~ droplevels(factor(names(.), levels = names(ratios)))   ))

title: Authors and Citation
text: Justin Brantley. Author, maintainer.

what: Utilities for Proofreading and Typesetting Books
title: Utilities for Proofreading and Typesetting Books
text: goal letterblasteR facilitate typesetting ready--print editions public domain texts. templates utility functions provided letterblasteR generic modular enough used way see fit, designed following workflow mind. Online repositories like Internet Archive Google Books host scans physical book pages well optical character recognition (OCR) data page. works enter public domain United States, Distributed Proofreaders volunteers proofread text multiple times correct scanning errors standardize basic formatting. Project Gutenberg volunteers convert proofread public domain works standard formats (e.g. plain text, HTML, epub). stage, text usually undergone several rounds proofreading multiple people. Generally, texts accurately represent source material free scanning errors typos. However, headings, tables, figures, elements require additional markup typesetting work print. letterblasteR comes ! Details subject change letterblasteR early development, general idea volunteer… Selects Project Gutenberg work convert requests creation new Letterblaster Press repository project. Uses letterblasteR templates utilities combine multiple versions work (e.g. HTML, epub; different editions) single source document formatted Pandoc’s Markdown. ensures available markup (e.g. emphasized text) appears final text. Adds, edits, standardizes semantic markup headings, tables, figures, inline formatting, special environments like poetry, letters, & mathematics. manual iterative process, letterblasteR templates utilities help streamline process. Extends letterblasteR templates define structure formatting finished book(s). Renders PDF(s) uses letterblasteR utilities impose ready--print versions PDF.

title: Utilities for Proofreading and Typesetting Books
text: following principles guide early design decisions project gets ground: Objective: produce ready--print PDFs public domain works amateur bookbinder mind One work can many designs, physical dimensions, formatting, style. Provide page-level (imposition) PDF design. Use vdiff tools proofread every two-page spread design PDF. design can many imposed PDFs accommodate different paper stock sizes. Generally, amateur bookbinder requires imposed PDFs stock sizes roughly A3–A4. Imposed PDFs note ideal grain direction, providing options short- long-grain paper possible. Signature sizes optimized imposition. Design PDFs printing. Forgo markup intended electronic formats hyperlinks screen reader hints; disable PDF features reduce bloat. (example, marking “Mr.” abbreviation useful screen-reader, serves purpose print. However, marking “NASA” acronym “FBI” initialism desired may require special typesetting like small caps.) Use embedable fonts embed PDFs. add fonts source control. Use Pandoc’s Markdown source truth. Favor semantic markup formatting markup. can represented using Pandoc’s Markdown, . Otherwise, wrap semantic element fenced div bracketed span use Pandoc filter wrap element custom LaTeX environment pass element custom LaTeX function, respectively. Otherwise, consider using Pandoc template partials. example, book complex chapter page containing pre-title text, title, subtitle, epigraph, image broken chapter-level files, yaml metadata block containing aforementioned elements. root template include chapter file, rendering partial template takes care typesetting complex chapter page. last resort – let’s really try avoid – raw LaTeX chunk can used long corresponding non-LaTeX chunk use fallback event source markdown files rendered another format. ideal markdown document free external markup (HTML, LaTeX, etc.), free formatting markup (e.g. small caps), limited UTF-8 text semantic markup (e.g. letter environment, acronym). formatting details factored Pandoc template(s) design. letterblasteR provide generators customize boilerplate templates common patterns. Aim produce professional-quality typeset. Use advanced fonts typographic features available, get fussy hyphenation. Let Elements Typographic Style Visual Display Quantitative Information guide design decisions. Design decisions honor original work era produced, favor good typography precise historical accuracy facsimile original work. Allow typesetting software alter fine-tune spacing, otherwise honor archaic punctuation, spelling, formatting. Report text errors back source (Distributed Proofreaders, Project Gutenberg, etc.). Follow conventions reproducible research new versions can recompiled minimal effort. Capture common transformations modular semantic functions (e.g. drop_div(".book-metadata"), drop_null_anchors()). Create custom Pandoc filters, use liberally checking new source avoid massive diffs inconsequential differences like spacing word wrapping.

title: Helper functions called by dev_check() — dev_check_helpers
text: dev_check() convenience wrapper runs following checks sequence: dev_lint() tidies source code styler::style_pkg(). dev_document() updates package documentation vignettes calls devtools::document() usethis::use_tidy_description(). dev_spell_check() checks spelling package documentation vignettes calls spelling::spell_check_package() spelling::update_wordlist(). dev_build_site() builds documentation site calls dev_publish_vignettes() pkgdown::build_site(), loads preview RStudio Viewer pane. dev_coverage() runs code coverage checks calls covr::package_coverage() covr::file_report().

title: Helper functions called by dev_check() — dev_check_helpers
text: dev_spell_check() first checks package documentation vignettes spelling errors. spelling errors found, custom dictionary re-sorted, deduplicated, purged unused words. spelling errors found, user confirmation required updating custom dictionary; otherwise error thrown.

title: Helper functions called by dev_check() — dev_check_helpers
text: pkgdown::build_site() generates documentation site package, including "Articles" section contains rendered package vignettes. works great simple demos, pkgdown::build_site() re-renders every R Markdown vignette building site, making impractical long-running vignettes code requires specific resources. function introduces concept vignettes-raw subdirectory place notebooks R Markdown documents run manually. enable feature, simply render R Markdown documents vignettes-raw keep_md: true. ready "publish", simply check rendered *.md file (plus supporting files) source control. dev_publish_vignettes() employs simple hack add documents package site without re-rendering. Briefly, vignettes-raw directory copied vignettes directory, name changes applied pkgdown::build_site() uses (pre-rendered) Markdown file, rather source R Markdown file.

title: Visualize harmonious layouts — plot_layouts
code: plot_layouts(layouts)   layouts |>   subset(     layouts$page_ratio %in% c("fourth", "fifth") &       dplyr::between(ratios[layouts$text_ratio], 1.2, 1.6) &       dplyr::between(layouts$text_pct, 0.5, 0.75)   ) |>   plot_layouts()

title: Harmonious ratios — ratios
text: simple named vector "harmonious" ratios.

title: Harmonious ratios — ratios
text: named vector

title: Harmonious ratios — ratios
text: Ratios fall following categories: chromatic ratios derived western music theory golden ratio "triple" "double octave" ratios -- set includes simple ratios 1:1 (unison), 1:2 (octave), 1:3, 1:4 ratios (except 1:1) appear pairs, e.g. "major third" (1.25) "inverse major third" (0.8). Ratios greater one imply portrait orientation, ratios less one imply landscape orientation. Vector sorted square (unison) tallest/widest proportions.

title: Harmonious ratios — ratios
code: cbind(ratios) #>                          ratios #> unison                1.0000000 #> minor 2nd             1.0666667 #> inverse minor 2nd     0.9375000 #> major 2nd             1.1250000 #> inverse major 2nd     0.8888889 #> minor 3rd             1.2000000 #> inverse minor 3rd     0.8333333 #> major 3rd             1.2500000 #> inverse major 3rd     0.8000000 #> fourth                1.3333333 #> inverse fourth        0.7500000 #> fifth                 1.5000000 #> inverse fifth         0.6666667 #> minor 6th             1.6000000 #> inverse minor 6th     0.6250000 #> golden ratio          1.6180340 #> inverse golden ratio  0.6180340 #> major 6th             1.6666667 #> inverse major 6th     0.6000000 #> minor 7th             1.7777778 #> inverse minor 7th     0.5625000 #> major 7th             1.8750000 #> inverse major 7th     0.5333333 #> octave                2.0000000 #> inverse octave        0.5000000 #> triple                3.0000000 #> inverse triple        0.3333333 #> double octave         4.0000000 #> inverse double octave 0.2500000

what: Round proportions to nearest harmonious ratios — round_ratios

title: Round proportions to nearest harmonious ratios — round_ratios
code: round_ratios(   h,   w = 1,   target = c("nearest", "taller", "wider"),   tolerance = 0.01 )

title: Round proportions to nearest harmonious ratios — round_ratios
text: h, w pairwise height & width vectors representing input proportions target whether identify nearest harmonious ratio (default) limit solutions input proportion may taller/wider harmonious ratio, see Details & Examples tolerance consider harmonious ratios within ±tolerance input ratios, degrees

title: Round proportions to nearest harmonious ratios — round_ratios
text: Returns named vector rounded proportions. Proportions within ±tolerance harmonious ratio NA.

title: Round proportions to nearest harmonious ratios — round_ratios
text: Input proportions compared harmonious ratios converting angles degrees(). Rounding considers harmonious ratios within ±tolerance (degrees) input proportion. default, nearest harmonious ratio returned, target argument can used favor actual proportions run tall wide. making page layout decisions, can useful prefer proportions along spine little wider ideal ratio. bound, optical foreshortening along spine tends bring perceived ratio back harmony.

title: Round proportions to nearest harmonious ratios — round_ratios
code: round_ratios(3, 2) #> fifth  #>   1.5   round_ratios(2.9999, 2) #> fifth  #>   1.5  round_ratios(3.0001, 2) #> fifth  #>   1.5   round_ratios(c(2.9999, 3.0001), 2, tolerance = 1e-6) #> <NA> <NA>  #>   NA   NA   round_ratios(c(2.9999, 3.0001), 2, target = "taller") #>  <NA> fifth  #>    NA   1.5  round_ratios(c(2.9999, 3.0001), 2, target = "wider") #> fifth  <NA>  #>   1.5    NA

title: Generate sample text — sample_text
code: sample_text(3) #> [1] "There was a sound of dry leaves outside."    #> [2] "Three for a dime, the young peddler cried."  #> [3] "The price is fair for a good antique clock." sample_text(3, wrap = 42) #> [1] "s are paved with sticky tar. Those thistle" #> [2] "e meter says. The key you designed will fi" #> [3] ". Breathe deep and smell the piny air. Bir"
